title: Tech tasks replace household chores as parents pay kids £20 per job
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 16, 2015, 17:22 BST - UK Markets closed Tech tasks replace household chores as parents pay kids £20 per job By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph – 1 hour 13 minutes ago 262.50 +2.8500 
Half of parents have paid a child £20 for a single digital chore as adults tap their kids for their technological nous, Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) research has found 
Giving a child pocket money to buy sweets as a reward for doing household chores is a thing of the past. 
Doing the dishes has been replaced with iPod duty , according to research from Barclays, which has released a mobile banking app for 11 to 15-year-olds. 
Half of UK parents ask their children to help out with digital chores in return for pocket money , such as setting up a new mobile phone, uploading photos to social media, recording TV shows and even creating an online dating profile. 
A third of children were also paid to help their grandparents with technology, the survey of 2,000 people found. 
This is a far cry from the household chores that the parents surveyed remember doing in their youth. One in two parents said they did the washing up to earn their pocket money, while a third washed the car and 23pc collected the groceries. 
Others hung up the laundry, watered the garden and raked leaves. 
"The custom of giving children pocket money for leisurely pursuits or treats really took off through the 20th century," said Lyn Wall, curator of the Museum of Childhood in Edinburgh. 
"Initially children would buy comics, sweets and small toys such as marbles and spinning tops in return for chores of polishing shoes, going to the shops or cutting the grass." 
The going rate for household jobs has also changed as adults tap their children for their digital know-how, with half of parents admitting they have paid up to £20 for an individual digital chore . 
"Apart from sweets, the items children spend their money on has dramatically changed over the years, and the chores that children are helping with in return for pocket money have changed too," Ms Wall said. 
Despite children's technological savvy, the Barclays research found that seven in 10 parents hand out pocket money in cash form, with just 19pc using direct debit or payment apps . 
As that pocket money no longer goes on trips to the corner shop for penny sweets and a magazine, and with commerce moving swiftly online , Barclays is launching a mobile banking app to help teenagers manage their hard-earned piles of £20 notes . 
The bank hopes that the app, which is available on iOS and Android, will teach digitally native 11 to 15-year-olds to track and manage their finances. 
"We are moving into a digital age and hope that the app will help support parents across the country in encouraging their children to take responsibility for their pocket money earnings," said Barclays' Luke Christoforidis. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) will provide them with a tool to confidentially carry out their banking needs with ease and speed via their preferred channel."
